sections.title: Lobachevskian geometry in image recognition
sections.abstract:
In this paper we extend the Mumford--Sharon
\cite{sm06} approach to analyse plane domains equipped with a geometrical structure.
We describe the corresponding fields of differential invariants and use them to classify (or recognize) domains.
sections.author: N.\,Konovenko \and V.\, Lychagin
sections.introduction:
Conformal geometry plays an important role in $2$-dimensional image recognition studies.
This is based on observation that angles but not distances are important in recognition of images.

In \cite{sm06}
E. Sharon and D. Mumford suggested an approach for analysis of $2$-dimensional shapes by the conformal group.
Namely, they study plane domains with smooth boundaries up to conformal equivalence.
Domains in their approach are assumed to be empty, i. e. they do not carry any geometrical structure except the conformal one.

In this paper we extend their approach to analyze $2$-dimensional domains equipped with a some geometrical object.
We study in details  cases when domains are considered together with functions, differential $1$-forms or foliations on its and two such "decorated" domains are equivalent if there is a conformal mapping of them which equalizes the corresponding geometrical objects.

First of all we remark that the Riemann conformal mapping theorem transforms the problem to study equivalence of functions, differential $1$-forms or foliations on the Lobachevsky plane with respect to the group of M\"{o}bius transformations.

Secondly, application of Lie--Tresse theorem
\cite{kl13}
allows us to find fields of rational differential invariants for the different actions of the group $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ of the M\"{o}bius transformations.
These fields separate regular orbits of actions of the M\"{o}bius transformations on the jet-spaces of functions, differential $1$-forms and foliations respectively and give complete solutions of the equivalence problem for regular cases.

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
main_part:
Let $D\subset \mathbb{R}^{2}(\simeq \mathbb{C})$ be a simply connected domain with smooth boundary and let $\mathbb{D}=\{x^{2}+y^{2}\leq 1\}$ be the unit disk.
The Riemann theorem states that there exists a conformal mapping
$\varphi_{D}:D\rightarrow \mathbb{D}$ and two such mappings, say $\varphi_{D}$ and $\widetilde{\varphi}_{D}$, differ,
$\widetilde{\varphi}_{D}=\varphi_{D}\circ \lambda^{-1}$, on M\"{o}bius transformation of the disk:
$
\lambda: z \rightarrow e^{2 \pi i \theta}(z-a)/(1-\overline{a}z),
$
where $a \in \mathbb{D}$, $\theta \in \mathbb{R} / \mathbb{Z}$.
The group of M\"{o}bius transformations of the disk is isomorphic to $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ and defines the Lobachevskian geometry on the disk.
The corresponding representation of Lie algebra $\mathfrak{sl}_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ by vector fields has the form:
$$
%\begin{array}{ll}
X=y\partial_{x}-x\partial_{y}, \quad
Y=(1-x^{2}+y^{2})\partial_{x}+2xy\partial_{y}, \quad Z=(1-x^{2}+y^{2})\partial_{y}-2xy\partial_{x}.
%\end{array}
$$
It is known, that the M\"{o}bius transformations preserve the metric
$
g=t^{-2}(dx^{2}+dy^{2}),
$
where $t=1-x^{2}-y^{2}$, and have, in addition, the following invariant geometrical structures:
 symplectic structure
$
\Omega = t^{-2}dx \wedge dy;
$
 complex structure
$
I=\partial y \otimes dx - \partial_{x} \otimes dy.
$
By using the conformal mappings $\varphi_{D}$ one may transfer geometrical objects given on open domains into the corresponding objects on the unit disk.
Moreover, two such objects are equivalent with respect to conformal transformations if and only if their images on the unit disk are equivalent with respect to M\"{o}bius transformations.

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

As the first example of such geometrical objects we'll consider domains together with a given smooth function.

Let us denote by $J^{k}$ the manifolds of $k$-jets of smooth functions defined on the unit disk $\mathbb{D}$, and by
$(x,y,u,u_{10},u_{01},u_{11},\ldots)$ we denote the standard canonical coordinates in $J^{k}$.
The value of $u_{ij}$
on $k$-jet $[f]^{k}_{a}$ of the function $f$ is equal to $\frac{\partial^{i+j}f}{\partial x^{i}\partial y^{j}}(a)$.
Our goal is to find differential invariants of the prolonged action of $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ on $J^{k}$.

Because the Lie group $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ is algebraic and the jet-spaces $J^{k}$ are  algebraic manifolds we'll apply the Lie--Tresse theorem
\cite{kl13} to describe fields of differential invariants.
Remark also that in this case such invariants separate regular orbits.

Namely, by differential invariant of order $\leq k$ we mean a rational function on $J^{k}$ which is invariant under prolonged action of  $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ and by invariant differentiation we mean a total vector field
$
A\frac{d}{dx}+B\frac{d}{dy},
$
where $A$ and $B$ are rational functions on $J^{l}$, for some $l \geq 0$, which commutes with the $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-action.
As the first invariant of the $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-action we take the Liouville differential form:
$
\omega = u_{10}dx+u_{01}dy
$
on the space of $1$-jets $J^{1}$.
Remark that this form is invariant under lifts of arbitrary diffeomorhisms.

Using the complex structure $I$ we get the differential $1$-form:
$
I\omega=-u_{01}dx+u_{10}dy,
$
which is now invariant under lift of conformal transformations.
If follows from the construction that horizontal differential $1$-forms $\omega_{1}=\omega$ and $\omega_{2}=I\omega$ define the coframe in domain, where
$
T=u_{10}^{2}+u_{01}^{2} \neq 0,
$
and this coframe is invariant under conformal transformations.

The dual frame is formed by $PSL_{2}$-invariant total differentiations:
$$
\nabla_{1}=T^{-1}(u_{10}\frac{d}{dx}+u_{01}\frac{d}{dy}), \quad 
\nabla_{2}=T^{-1}(-u_{01}\frac{d}{dx}+u_{10}\frac{d}{dy}).
$$
It is easy to check that the structure equations for coframe $\langle w_{1},w_{2}\rangle$ has the following form:
$
%\bigg \{
%\begin{array}{ll}
\widehat{d}w_{1}=0, \quad
\widehat{d}w_{2}=J_{2}w_{1} \wedge w_{2},
%\end{array}
$
where by $\widehat{d}$ we denoted the total de Rham differential.
Here
$
J_{2}=T^{-1}(u_{20}+u_{02})
$
is the differential $PSL_{2}$-invariant of order $2$.

Two more differential invariants are easy to get. They are
$
J_{0}=u
$
in $0$-order and
$
J_{1}=g(\omega, \omega)=t^{2}T
$
in the $1$-st order.
Applying invariant derivations $\nabla_{1}$ and $\nabla_{2}$ to the last invariant we get two more differential invariants of order $2$:
$$
J_{11}=\nabla_{1}(J_{1})=\frac{2}{T}\bigg((u_{10}^{2}u_{20}+2u_{10}u_{01}u_{11}+u_{01}^{2}u_{02})+
2t(xu_{10}+yu_{01}) \bigg),
$$$$
J_{12}=\nabla_{2}(J_{1})=\frac{2}{T}\bigg(u_{10}u_{01}(u_{02}-u_{20})+(u_{10}^{2}-u_{01}^{2})u_{11}+
2t(yu_{10}-xu_{01}) \bigg).
$$
We say now that $k$-jet $[f]_{a}^{k}$, $k \geq 1$, of a function $f$ at the point $a\in\mathbb{D}$ is \textit{regular} if $d_{a}f \neq 0$.
$PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-orbits of regular jets we call \textit{regular} too.
As we have noted the prolonged actions of $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ in the jet spaces $J^{k}$ are algebraic actions of the  algebraic group on algebraic manifolds.
Therefore, computing codimensions of regular orbits and using
\cite{kl13}, we get the following result.
\begin{theorem}
The field of rational differential $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-invariants on the jet spaces of functions on the unit disk is generated by invariants $(J_{0}, J_{1}, J_{2})$ and their invariant derivatives
$\nabla_{1}^{i} \nabla_{2}^{j}(J_{l})$.
The field separates regular orbits.
\end{theorem}
Instead of using the invariant derivatives $\nabla_{1}$ and $\nabla_{2}$ one may also use the Tresse derivatives:
$
\frac{D}{DJ_{0}}, \quad \frac{D}{DJ_{1}}.
$
To find them assume that
$
\frac{D}{DJ_{i}}=A_{i1}\nabla_{1}+A_{i2}\nabla_{2}
$
for some functions $A_{ij}$, $i,j=1,2$.
Then
$$
\frac{DJ_{j}}{DJ_{i}}=A_{i1}\nabla_{1}J_{j}+A_{i2}\nabla_{2}J_{j}=\delta_{ij}.
$$
Solving this system with respect to $\| A_{ij} \|$ we find that
$$
\frac{D}{DJ_{0}}=\nabla_{1}-\frac{J_{11}}{J_{12}}\nabla_{2},
\quad \frac{D}{DJ_{1}}=\frac{1}{J_{12}}\nabla_{2},
\quad
\nabla_{1}=\frac{D}{DJ_{0}}+J_{11}\frac{D}{DJ_{1}},
\quad 
\nabla_{2}=J_{12}\frac{D}{DJ_{1}}.
$$
Therefore, the above theorem can be reformulated in terms of the Tresse derivatives as follows.
\begin{theorem}
The field of rational differential M\"{o}bius invariants of functions on the unit disk is generated by invariants
$(J_{0}, J_{1}, J_{11}, J_{12}, J_{2})$ and their Tresse derivatives $\frac{D^{a+b}J}{DJ^{a}_{0}DJ^{b}_{1}}$.
\end{theorem}
The last theorem allows us to get $PSL_{2}$-classification of smooth functions on the unit disk.

Given such a function $f$ and an invariant $J$ then by $J(f)$ we denote the value of $J$ on $f$.
We say that function $f$ is \textit{regular} on the disk if $J_{1}(f) \neq 0$ and $J_{12}(f) \neq 0$ on the disk.
Straightforward computations show that the following result holds.
\begin{lemma}
Let $f$ be a regular function on the disk. Then the map
$
\Phi_{f}: \mathbb{D} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{2},
\quad \Phi_{f}=\bigg(J_{0}(f), J_{1}(f)\bigg),
$
is a local homeomorphism.
\end{lemma}
Let $f$ be a regular function. Then it follows from the lemma, that there are smooth
functions $A$, $B$, $C$ such that
\begin{equation}
\label{1}
%\begin{array}{ll}
J_{11}(f)=A\big(f, J_{1}(f)\big), \quad
J_{12}(f)=B\big(f, J_{1}(f)\big), \quad
J_{2}(f)=C\big(f, J_{1}(f)\big)
%\end{array}
\end{equation}
on the disk.
We consider (\ref{1}) as a system of differential equations on function $f$ given functions $A$, $B$, $C$.
Remark that (\ref{1}) is a overdetermined system and compatibility conditions take the form:
\begin{equation}
\label{2}
\begin{array}{cc}
J_{12}\frac{DJ_{11}}{DJ_{1}}-J_{11}\frac{DJ_{12}}{DJ_{1}}=J_{2}J_{12}, \\
\qquad \\
2J_{1}^{2}J_{11}\frac{DJ_{2}}{DJ_{1}}-J_{1}J_{11}\frac{DJ_{11}}{DJ_{1}}-J_{1}J_{12}\frac{DJ_{12}}{DJ_{1}}
=J_{1}J_{2}J_{11}-2J_{1}^{2}J_{2}^{2}%+ \\
+2J_{1}-J_{11}^{2}-J_{12}^{2}.
\end{array}
\end{equation}
Under conditions (\ref{2}) system (\ref{1}) is a  $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-invariant completely integrable system.
The solution space of this system has therefore dimension $3$ and its solutions are uniquely determined by value of their $1$-jet at a fixed point.
In other words, system (\ref{1}) is automorphic system in the sence that  the group $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ acts in a transitive and free way on the solution space.
Summarizing, we arrive at the following $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-classification.
\begin{theorem}
The regular functions $f$ and $\widetilde{f}$ are $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-equivalents if and only if they have the same representive functions  $A$, $B$, $C$ and $Im \Phi_{f}=Im \Phi_{\widetilde{f}}$.
\end{theorem}%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

Is this section we consider conformal classification of plane domains equipped with oriented foliations.
Conformal classes of such foliations can be identified with differential $1$-forms
$\theta \in \Omega^{1}(\mathbb{D})$,
normalized by requirement $g(\theta,\theta)=1$.
Let's denote by $T_{1}^{\ast} \mathbb{D} \subset T^{\ast} \mathbb{D}$ the subbundle of covectors, having length one, and let $\pi : T_{1}^{\ast} \mathbb{D} \rightarrow \mathbb{D}$ be the corresponding bundle.
Then sections of $\pi$ we identify with oriented foliations in $\mathbb{D}$.

The $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-action on $\mathbb{D}$ naturally lifts to bundle $\pi$ and below we investigate differential invariants of this action.
First of all we remark that coframe $\langle \omega_{1}, \omega_{2} \rangle$(\ref{22}) on $T^{\ast} \mathbb{D}$ can be restricted on $\pi$. The resulting coframe
$$
\omega_{1} = t^{-1}\big(\sin \omega dx + \cos \omega dy \big),
\quad 
\omega_{2} = t^{-1}\big(-\cos \omega dx + \sin \omega dy \big),
$$
where $\omega$ is an angle in fibres of $\pi$, is $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-invariant too.

The dual frame consist of two $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-invariant total derivations:
$$
\delta_{1} = t \bigg(\sin\omega \frac{d}{dx} + \cos\omega \frac{d}{dy} \bigg),
\quad
\delta_{2} = t \bigg(-\cos\omega \frac{d}{dx} + \sin\omega \frac{d}{dy} \bigg).
$$
The structure equations
$
\widehat{d}\omega_{1} + J_{1} \omega_{1} \wedge \omega_{2} = 0,
\quad \widehat{d}\omega_{2} + J_{2} \omega_{1} \wedge \omega_{2} = 0
$
give us two differential invariants of order $1$:
$$
J_{1}=t \big(\sin\omega\cdot \omega_{10} + \cos\omega\cdot \omega_{01}\big)-2\big(x \cdot \cos\omega-y \cdot \sin\omega \big),
$$$$
J_{2}=t \big(\cos\omega\cdot \omega_{10} - \sin\omega\cdot \omega_{01}\big)+2\big(x\cdot \sin\omega+y\cdot \cos\omega \big).
$$\begin{theorem} 
(1) The field of rational differential $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-invariants of oriented foliations on the unit disk $\mathbb{D}$ is generated by differential invariants $J_{1}$, $J_{2}$ of order $1$ and invariant derivations $\delta_{1}$, $\delta_{2}$.

(2) This field separates $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-orbits in $J^{k}(\pi)$.

(3) Differential syzygies are generated by the following syzygy in order $2$:
\begin{equation}
\label{66}
\delta_{2}(J_{1})+\delta_{1}(J_{2})+J_{1}^{2}+J_{2}^{2}=4.
\end{equation}
\end{theorem}
We say that differential form $\theta$ of length $1$ is \textit{regular} on the unit disk if functions $J_{1}(\theta)$ and $J_{2}(\theta)$ are independent.
If follows from the above theorem that the restriction of the field of differential invariants on a regular foliation is completely determined by invariants $\delta_{i}(J_{j})$, or by functions $J_{1}(\theta)$, $J_{2}(\theta)$ and functions $F_{ij}$, where
\begin{equation}
\label{7}
\delta_{i}\big(J_{j}(\theta)\big)=F_{ij}\big(J_{1}(\theta), J_{2}(\theta)\big)
\end{equation}
subjected to syzygy relation
(\ref{66}).
System of differential equations
(\ref{7}) is $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-invariant and automorphic.
Solutions of the system are just $SL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$-orbits of foliations.
To give a geometric interpretation of the invariant description of regular foliations consider plane $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ with fixed coordinate system, say
$(p,q)$, and mapping
$
J_{\theta}: \mathbb{D} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{2},
$
where
$
J_{\theta}=\big(J_{1}(\theta), J_{2}(\theta)\big).
$
This mapping is a diffeomorphism for regular foliation.

Functions $F_{ij}$ defines two vector fields
$$
A_{\theta}=F_{11}(p,q)\partial_{p}+F_{12}(p,q)\partial_{q},
\quad B_{\theta}=F_{21}(p,q)\partial_{p}+F_{22}(p,q)\partial_{q},
$$
on $ImJ_{\theta}$ which are images of derivations $\delta_{1}$ and $\delta_{2}$.
The structure equations show that
$
\big[A_{\theta}, B_{\theta}\big]=pA_{\theta}+qB_{\theta},
$
and the syzygy relation gives an addition:
$
F_{21}+F_{12}+p^{2}+q^{2}=4.
$
Then theorem $6$ can be reformulated in the following way.
\begin{theorem}
Two regular oriented foliations on the unit disk are $PSL_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ equivalent if and only if domains $ImJ_{\theta}$ and $ImJ_{\widetilde{\theta}}$ as well as vector fields $(A_{\theta}, B_{\theta})$ and
$(A_{\widetilde{\theta}}, B_{\widetilde{\theta}})$ coincide.
\end{theorem}%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
